Protein families: Sea anemone BDS toxin family

Protein families: Sea anemone BDS toxin family
Function [CC]: Potently and selectively blocks the H(+)-gated sodium channel ASIC3 (ACCN3). The blockade is rapid and reversible. Does not block isoform ASIC1a and isoform ASIC1b of ASIC1 (ACCN2), nor ASIC2 (ACCN1). It also inhibits heteromeric ASIC2b-ASIC3 channel, while it has less affinity for ASIC1b-ASIC3, ASIC1a-ASIC3, and no effect on the ASIC2a-ASIC3 channels.

Protein families: Peptidase M12B family
Function [CC]: Promotes coagulation and thrombin-dependent platelet aggregation. Induces lethal thrombosis at relatively low doses when administered to mice by intravenous injection. Catalyzes the conversion of prothrombin to alpha-thrombin through formation of a thrombin intermediate. Has metalloproteinase activity but does not degrade components of the extracellular matrix. Inhibits collagen interaction with platelet receptors expressed on glycoprotein IIb- IIIa complex. Induces defibrinogenation but has no hemorragic activity.

Protein names: Cobra venom factor precursor (CVF) (Complement C3 homolog)
Protein families: Contains 1 NTR domain
Function [CC]: Complement-activating protein in cobra venom.
Post-translational modification: First processed by the removal of 4 Arg residues by furin- type protease, forming two chains, alpha and gamma/beta precursor, linked by a disulfide bond. Probably, the cobrin cleaves the C3a- like domain and then the C3d-like domain, generating the mature cobra venom factor (CVF). This mature CVF is composed of three chains: alpha, gamma and beta. These chains are linked by a disulfide bond between the alpha and gamma chains and another one between the gamma and beta chains.

Protein families: Conotoxin P-superfamily
Function [CC]: Elicits "spasmodic" symptomatology.

Protein families: Conotoxin P-superfamily
Function [CC]: Intracranial injection into mice of 10 pmol/g of the peptide induces running in circles and hyperactivity. At higher doses (50 pmol/g), the mice exhibit running and climbing symptoms for close to one hour. Between 130 and 150 pmol/g, characteristic "spasmodic" symptomatology is elicited. A hand clap would make mice jump high and start running rapidly. When exposed to a loud hand clap, or if the cage cover were dropped, the mice lose motor control and exhibit seizure-like symptoms from which they eventually recover. At the highest doses tested (over 250 pmol/g), after the characteristic spasmodic symptomatology, lethality occurs. Injection of a similar dose range intramuscularly into Siamese fighting fish elicited no unusual symptomatology.

Protein families: Snake toxin family. Type IA cytotoxin subfamily
Function [CC]: Shows cytolytic activity (By similarity).
Toxic dose: LD(50) is 4.9 mg/kg by intravenous injection.

Function [CC]: Alpha-conotoxins act on postsynaptic membranes, they bind to the nicotinic acetylcholine receptors (nAChR) and thus inhibit them. This peptide blocks mammalian nicotinic acetylcholine receptors composed of alpha-3/beta-4 subunits.

Protein families: Conotoxin A-superfamily. Alpha-type family
Function [CC]: Alpha-conotoxins act on postsynaptic membranes, they bind to the nicotinic acetylcholine receptors (nAChR) and thus inhibit them. It is highly active against the neuromuscular receptor in frog but not in mice. In contrast, it induces seizures when injected centrally in mice and rats. It targets neuronal nAChRs in mammals. It blocks homomeric alpha-7 nicotinic receptors with the highest apparent affinity and homomeric alpha-9 receptors with 8-fold lower affinity. It inhibits alpha-bungarotoxin binding. It has no effect on receptors composed of alpha-2/beta-2, alpha-3/beta-2, alpha-4/beta-2, alpha-2/beta-4, alpha-3/beta-4, or alpha-4/beta-4 subunit combinations. It acts voltage- independently.

Protein families: Conotoxin A-superfamily. Alpha-type family

In contrast to other alpha- conotoxins, this peptide has no detectable activity at the muscle subtype of receptor, but instead, it potently targets neuronal nAChR. It blocks alpha-3/beta-2 subunits of mammalian nAChR. It has an activity 2 to 4 orders of magnitude less potent on other nAChR subunit combinations.

Permeabilizes a variety of cells. Forms large pores which allows the release of large proteins almost as rapidly as small organic molecules and inorganic ions. At sublytic concentrations, the toxin also inhibits protein kinase C and endogenous voltage-gated cation selective (sodium, calcium) channels occurring in the nervous and cardiovascular systems.

Function [CC]: Induces sleep-like symptoms in mice of all ages.

Protein families: Conotoxin O-superfamily
Function [CC]: Causes convulsions mice.

Protein families: Conotoxin O-superfamily. Delta-type family
Function [CC]: Delta-conotoxins bind to voltage-sensitive sodium channel (VSSC) and inhibit the inactivation process.

Protein families: Conotoxin O-superfamily. Delta-type family
Function [CC]: Delta-conotoxins bind to voltage-sensitive sodium channel (VSSC) and inhibit the inactivation process. Injection of this peptide in the head region of garden snail induces retraction of the head and body into shell. This is followed by secretion of viscous green slime and a convulsive undulation into and out of the shell. No apparent biological activity was observed when a much greater dose of peptide was injected peritoneally into mice.

Protein families: Conotoxin O-superfamily. Delta-type family
Function [CC]: Delta-conotoxins bind to voltage-sensitive sodium channel and inhibit the inactivation process. In mice, injection of this toxin causes hyperactivity, rapid running, limb extension, and death. In fish, the peptide elicites spurts of rapid swimming, with twisted motions, quivering fins and the lockjaw extended mouth syndrome. Rigid paralysis and death are observed at higher doses. In mollusks, this peptide is inactive. Injection of this peptide together with the kappa-conotoxin PVIIA causes the sudden tetanus of prey (STOP) syndrome, which is a single, lethal "fin- pop" in envenomated fish.
Post-translational modification: The difference between delta-conotoxin PVIA and [deamido]- delta-conotoxin PVIA lies in the state of amidation of Gly-80.

Protein families: Conotoxin O-superfamily. Delta-type family
Function [CC]: Delta-conotoxins bind to voltage-sensitive sodium channel (VSSC) and inhibit the inactivation process. Potent paralytic toxin in vertebrate and invertebrate systems. Its binding appears to be voltage-dependent.

Protein families: Conotoxin O-superfamily. Delta-type family
Function [CC]: Delta-conotoxins bind to voltage-sensitive sodium channel (VSSC) and inhibit the inactivation process. This toxin inhibits sodium channel inactivation in neuronal membranes from amphibians and mammals (Nav1.2a, Nav1.3, and Nav1.6) upon binding to receptor site 6, without affecting rat skeletal muscle (Nav1.4) and human cardiac muscle (Nav1.5) sodium channels.
Toxic dose: Dose that produces hyperactivity (ED(50)) is 1.8 pmol/g body mass (native toxin), 1.9 pmol/g body mass (synthetic toxin), and 3.9 pmol/g body mass (P13A mutant).

Protein families: Conotoxin O-superfamily. Delta-type family
Function [CC]: Delta-conotoxins bind to voltage-sensitive sodium channel (VSSC) and inhibit the inactivation process. Binding of this toxin is strongly calcium-dependent but not voltage- dependent. The binding site is most likely on the extracellular side of the sodium channel. Binds receptor sites on both mollusk and rat central nervous system, but despite its high affinity binding to rat sodium channel, it has no functional effect in vivo and in vitro on it. Has also no effect on Gambusia fish. Is important in mollusk for the paralysis of the prey. Upon injection of the peptide, a subordinate lobster assumes an exaggerated dominant posture (of a 'King-Kong' lobster!).

Protein families: Conotoxin O-superfamily. Delta-type family
Function [CC]: Delta-conotoxins bind to voltage-sensitive sodium channel (VSSC) and inhibit the inactivation process. Induces membrane depolarization and spontaneous repetitive firing of neurons.

Protein families: Conotoxin T-superfamily. Epsilon-type family
Function [CC]: Acts at presynaptic membranes, blocking the calcium channels. Causes hyperactivity upon intracranial injection into mice. Causes dorsal fins drooping in fish.
Post-translational modification: O-glycan consists of the disaccharide Gal-GalNAc.

Function [CC]: May specifically activate neuronal voltage-sensitive sodium channels (VSSC) at the resting membrane potential. Causes a marked contraction and extension of the caudal and dorsal fins in fish, and noticeable spontaneous contractions of isolated frog neuromuscular preparations.
Post-translational modification: Position 7 seems to be a glycosylated Ser or Thr.

Protein families: Conotoxin O-superfamily
Conotoxin O-superfamily
Function [CC]: May act on a voltage-gated nonspecific cation channel. Triggers depolarization and firing of action potential bursts in the caudodorsal neurons of lymnaea. This effect is due to activation or enhancement of a slow inward cation current that may underly endogenous bursting activity of these neurons.

Protein families: Conotoxin O-superfamily
Function [CC]: Inhibits the sodium channel. Binding studies indicate that this toxin belongs to the same group of sodium channel inhibitors as TTX, STX, and Mu-conotoxins. No effect was observed upon injections into mice and goldfish (25 microgrammes).

Protein families: Conotoxin A-superfamily. Kappa-type family
Function [CC]: Kappa-A-conotoxins bind and inhibit voltage-sensitive potassium channels. When injected intraperitoneally in fish, the peptide induces a period of rapid swimming followed by a spastic paralysis with stiff fibrillating fins. At high doses, the peptide is lethal to both fish and mice.
Post-translational modification: O-linked glycan consists of Hex3-HexNAc2 disaccharide (Probable).

Protein families: Conotoxin O-superfamily. Kappa-type family
Function [CC]: Kappa-conotoxins bind and inhibit voltage-sensitive potassium channels. The rat brain voltage-gated potassium channel protein Kv1.1 is resistant to this toxin, but the voltage-gated potassium channel protein Shaker (Drosophila) is sensitive. The interaction site between the Shaker channel and this toxin is within the S5-S6 loop of the Shaker channel. In fish, this toxin induces hyperactivity, followed by continuous contraction and extension of major fins, without immobilization or death. Injection of this peptide together with the delta-conotoxin PVIA causes the sudden tetanus of prey (STOP) syndrome, which is a single, lethal "fin-pop" in envenomated fish. In mice, induces hyperactivity.

Protein families: Conantokin family
Function [CC]: Induces sleep-like symptoms in young mice and hyperactivity in older mice. Inhibits N-methyl-D-aspartate (NMDA) receptor-mediated calcium influx in central nervous system neurons.

Protein families: Sea anemone tenebrosin family
Function [CC]: This cardiac stimulatory and hemolytic protein is a channel-forming and/or membrane-penetrating protein. Cytolytic effects include red blood cells hemolysis, platelet aggregation and lysis, cytotoxic and cytostatic effects on fibroblasts. Lethality in mammals has been ascribed to severe vasospasm of coronary vessels, cardiac arrhythmia, and inotropic effects.

Function [CC]: Has both toxic and EGF activity. Its EGF activity consists of rounding cells (morphological change) and inducing tyrosine phosphorylation of the EGFR in A431 cells, but with a lower potency that human EGF.
Toxic dose: PD(50) is 215 ug/kg to crabs. LD(50) is >1000 ug/kg to crabs.

Organism: Stichodactyla gigantea (Giant carpet anemone) (Gigantic sea anemone)

Toxic dose: LD(50) is 70 ug/kg to crabs.

Protein families: Peptidase S1 family
Function [CC]: Has kallikrein-like activity, releases bradykinin from kininogen. Catalyzes the hydrolysis of various arginine ester substrates for trypsin and thrombin and degrades both angiotensin I and II by cleavage of the dipeptide Asp-Arg from the NH2- terminal end. Fibrinogen is also degraded but a fibrin clot is not produced. May have a potentiating effect on potent hemorrhagic toxins present in the venom.
Post-translational modification: Extensively glycosylated, contains approximately 8 mol of monosaccharide per mol of toxin.

Function [CC]: Strong agonist of ryanodine receptors (calcium release channels). Induces voltage- and concentration-dependent subconductance states in both skeletal (RYR1 and RYR3) and cardiac (RYR2) ryanodine receptors by binding to a single, cytosolically accessible site different from the ryanodine binding site. Enhances calcium release.

Inhibits both skeletal (RYR1) and cardiac (RYR2) ryanodine receptors (calcium release channels). Probably blocks ryanodine receptors by generating a lipid product.

Function [CC]: Taicatoxin blocks the high threshold calcium channel current of excitable membranes in heart and does not affect the low threshold calcium channel current. The block is selective for calcium channels, reversible, does not affect single channel conductance but only changes channel gating, and is voltage dependent with higher affinity for inactivated channels. Is very toxic to mice.
Inhibits sodium channel inactivation in mammalian neurons and cardiac myocytes, and insect neurons.

Selectively inhibits activation of tetrodotoxin- resistant voltage-gated sodium channels (VGCC), followed by shifting activated voltage in a depolarizing direction. The binding site on VGSC is suggested to be site 4.

Function [CC]: Has no effect on Kv1 potassium channels.

Protein families: Alpha/beta-scorpion toxin family. Alpha-toxin subfamily
Function [CC]: Binds to the voltage-sensitive alpha-1G and alpha-1H T- type calcium channels (VSCC) with high affinity and inhibits the channels by modifying voltage-dependent gating. Do not affect alpha-1A (P/Q-type), alpha-1B (N-type), alpha-1C (L-type) and alpha-1E (R-type) calcium channels. Also interacts with voltage- sensitive sodium channels (VSSC) and slows their inactivation.

Protein families: Contains 21 ANK repeats
Function [CC]: Binds to high-affinity receptors that are localized in the presynaptic plasma membrane of the nerve terminal. Binding of toxin results in calcium influx into nerve terminals, activation of synaptic vesicle exocytosis, and ATP depletion. May act by forming cation-permeable pore-like tetramers that permeabilize the cell membrane and cause both neurotransmitter release and non vesicular leakage. Binding to receptors and activation of phospholipase C is not sufficient to trigger neurotransmitter release.
Post-translational modification: Alpha-latrotoxin is probably processed at its C-terminus.

Protein families: Contains 20 ANK repeats
Function [CC]: Causes neurotransmitter release at neuromuscular junctions. May act by forming cation-permeable pores in lipid membranes.

Protein families: Contains 1 C-type lectin family domain
Function [CC]: Binds to the platelet GPIb/IX receptor system and inhibits ristocetin-induced platelet agglutination in human platelet-rich plasma. Strongly inhibits platelet aggregation induced by ADP, calcium ionophore, thrombin and collagen. Does not inhibit U46619-induced platelet aggregation.

Protein families: Contains 1 C-type lectin family domain

Lethal toxin which possesses an inhibitory effect on direct electrical stimulation of the isolated hemi-diaphragm. Neither hemorrhagic nor hemolytic activities are detected. Phospholipase A2 activity, proteolytic activity and arginine esterolytic activity are absent.
Toxic dose: LD(50) is 0.135 mg/kg on mice.

Function [CC]: Forms pore that permeabilize the cell membrane. Promotes efflux of calcium from synaptosomes, causes hemolysis, and dissipates voltage gradients across muscle membrane. Potently inhibits the growth of bacteria and yeast. May function both in the prey capture strategy as well as protection from infectious organisms arising from prey ingestion.

Protein names: Mast cell degranulating peptide precursor (MCDP) (MCD peptide)
Function [CC]: Potent anti-inflammatory agent. But at low concentrations it mediates the degranulation of mast cells thus evoking an inflammatory response. Also acts as a neurotoxin capable of blocking a class of voltage-gated potassium channels.

Protein families: Melittin family
Function [CC]: Main toxin of bee venom with strong hemolytic activity. Integrates into cell membranes and has multiple effects, probably, as a result of its interaction with negatively charged phospholipids. It inhibits well known transport pumps such as the Na(+)-K(+)-ATPase and the H(+)-K(+)-ATPase. Increases the permeability of cell membranes to ions, particularly Na(+) and indirectly Ca(2+), because of the Na(+)-Ca(2+)-exchange (By similarity).

Protein families: Delta atracotoxin family
Function [CC]: Lethal neurotoxin. It causes a reduction in peak tetrodotoxin-sensitive sodium current, a slowing of sodium current inactivation and a hyperpolarising shift in the voltage at half- maximal activation. Effects are an increase in resting tension, a muscle fasciculation and a decrease in indirect twitch tension. It fails to affect tetrodotoxin-resistant sodium currents. This toxin is active on both insects and vertebrates.
